org.jdom2.output
Class AbstractXMLOutputProcessor

java.lang.Object
  org.jdom2.output.AbstractXMLOutputProcessor
All Implemented Interfaces:
XMLOutputProcessor
public abstract class AbstractXMLOutputProcessor
extends java.lang.Object
implements XMLOutputProcessor

This class provides a concrete implementation of XMLOutputProcessor for supporting the XMLOutputter.

Overview

This class is marked abstract even though all methods are fully implemented. The process*(...) methods are public because they match the XMLOutputProcessor interface but the remaining methods are all protected.

People who want to create a custom XMLOutputProcessor for XMLOutputter are able to extend this class and modify any functionality they want. Before sub-classing this you should first check to see if the Format class can get you the results you want.

Subclasses of this should have reentrant methods. This is easiest to accomplish simply by not allowing any instance fields. If your sub-class has an instance field/variable, then it's probably broken.

The Stacks

One significant feature of this implementation is that it creates and maintains both a NamespaceStack and FormatStack that are managed in the printElement(Writer, FormatStack, NamespaceStack, Element) method. The stacks are pushed and popped in that method only. They significantly improve the performance and readability of the code.

The NamespaceStack is only sent through to the printElement(Writer, FormatStack, NamespaceStack, Element) and printContent(Writer, FormatStack, NamespaceStack, List) methods, but the FormatStack is pushed through to all print* Methods.

Text Processing

In XML the concept of 'Text' can be loosely defined as anything that can be found between an Element's start and end tags, excluding Comments and Processing Instructions. When considered from a JDOM perspective, this means Text, CDATA and EntityRef content. This will be referred to as 'text-type content'

In the context of XMLOutputter, EntityRef content is considered to be text-type content. This happens because when XML is parsed the embedded entity reference tokens are (normally) expanded to their replacement text. If an EntityRef content has survived to this output stage it means that it cannot (or should not) be expanded. As a result, it should simply be output as it's escaped name in the form &refname;.

Consecutive text-type JDOM content is an especially hard problem because the complete set of consecutive values should be considered together. For example, there is a significant difference between the 'trimmed' result of two individual Text contents and the trimmed result of the same Text contents which are combined before trimming: consider two consecutive Text contents " X " and " Y " which (trimmed) should be output as: "X  Y" not "XY".

As a result, this class differentiates between stand-alone and consecutive text-type JDOM Content. If the content is determined to be stand-alone, it is fed to one of the printEntityRef(Writer, FormatStack, EntityRef), printCDATA(Writer, FormatStack, CDATA), or printText(Writer, FormatStack, Text) methods. If there is consecutive text-type content it is all fed together to the printTextConsecutive(Writer, FormatStack, List, int, int) method.

The above 4 methods for printing text-type content will all use the various text*(...) methods to produce output to the Writer.

Note: If the Format's TextMode is PRESERVE then all text-type content is considered to be stand-alone. In other words, printTextConsecutive() will never be called when the TextMode is PRESERVE.

Non-Text Content

Non-text content is processed via the respective print* methods. The usage should be logical based on the method name.

The general observations are:

  • printElement - maintains the Stacks, prints the element open tags, with attributes and namespaces. It checks to see whether the Element is text-only, or has non-text content. If it is text-only there is no indent/newline handling and it delegates to the correct text-type print method, otherwise it delegates to printContent.
  • printContent is called if there is a 'mixed' content list to output. It will always wrap each respective content call (one of a text-type print, a printTextConsecutive, or a non-text type print) with an indent and a newline.

Final Notes

No methods actually write to the destination Writer except the write(...) methods. Thus, all other methods do their respective processing and delegate the actual destination output to the write(Writer, char) or write(Writer, String) methods.

Only the text-type print methods (printCDATA, printText, printEntityRef, and printTextConsecutive) will call the text* methods.

There are two 'helper' methods which are simply there to reduce some code redundancy in the class. They do nothing more than that. Have a look at the source-code to see what they do. If you need them they may prove useful.

Author:
Rolf Lear
See Also:
XMLOutputter, XMLOutputProcessor

attributeEscapedEntitiesFilter

protected void attributeEscapedEntitiesFilter(java.io.Writer out,
                                              FormatStack fstack,
                                              java.lang.String value)
                                       throws java.io.IOException
This will take the three pre-defined entities in XML 1.0 ('<', '>', and '&' - used specifically in XML elements) and convert their character representation to the appropriate entity reference, suitable for XML element content. Further, some special characters (e.g. characters that are not valid in the current encoding) are converted to escaped representations.

Note: If FormatStack.getEscapeOutput() is false then no escaping will happen.

Parameters:
out - The destination Writer
fstack - The FormatStack
value - String Attribute value to escape.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the destination Writer fails.
IllegalDataException - if an entity can not be escaped

Parameters:

str - the String to write.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the Writer fails.

textCDATARaw

protected void textCDATARaw(java.io.Writer out,
                            java.lang.String str)
                     throws java.io.IOException
Write a CDATA's value to the destination. The value will not be formatted or modified in any way.

The input str will be wrapped in the <![CDATA[ and ]]> delimiters.

Parameters:
out - the destination Writer.
str - the CDATA's value.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the Writer fails.

textCDATACompact

protected void textCDATACompact(java.io.Writer out,
                                java.lang.String str)
                         throws java.io.IOException
Write a CDATA's value to the destination. The value will first be compacted (all leading and trailing whitespace will be removed and all internal whitespace will be be represented with a single ' ' character). If the CDATA contains only whitespace then nothing is output.

The results (if any) will be wrapped in the <![CDATA[ and ]]> delimiters.

Parameters:
out - the destination Writer.
str - the CDATA's value.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the Writer fails.

textCDATATrimFullWhite

protected void textCDATATrimFullWhite(java.io.Writer out,
                                      java.lang.String str)
                               throws java.io.IOException
Write a CDATA's value to the destination. The value will first be inspected. If the CDATA contains only whitespace then nothing is output, otherwise the entire input str will be wrapped in the <![CDATA[ and ]]> delimiters.

Parameters:
out - the destination Writer.
str - the CDATA's value.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the Writer fails.

                          throws java.io.IOException

Parameters:
out - the destination Writer.
str - the CDATA's value.

out - the destination Writer.

textEscapedEntitiesFilter

protected void textEscapedEntitiesFilter(java.io.Writer out,
                                         FormatStack fstack,
                                         char[] str,
                                         int left,
                                         int right)
                                  throws java.io.IOException
This will take the three pre-defined entities in XML 1.0 ('<', '>', and '&' - used specifically in XML elements) and convert their character representation to the appropriate entity reference, suitable for XML element content. Further, some special characters (e.g. characters that are not valid in the current encoding) are converted to escaped representations.

Note: If FormatStack.getEscapeOutput() is false then no escaping will happen.

Parameters:
out - The destination Writer
fstack - The FormatStack
str - char[] input to escape.
left - where in the input array (inclusive) to start escaping and writing.
right - where in the input array (exclusive) to end escaping and writing.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the destination Writer fails.
IllegalDataException - if an entity can not be escaped

printElement

protected void printElement(java.io.Writer out,
                            FormatStack fstack,
                            NamespaceStack nstack,
                            Element element)
                     throws java.io.IOException
This will handle printing of an Element.

This method arranges for outputting the Element infrastructure including Namespace Declarations and Attributes.

There has to be a fair amount of inspection to determine whether there is any content and whether it is all text-type content, and based on the required Format output, how to deal with the content. Alternatives (in 'fall-through' order) are:

  1. There is no content, then output just an empty element (depending on settings this may be either <element /> or <element></element>).
  2. There is only text-type content and the current Format settings would condense the text-type content to nothing, then output just an empty element (depending on settings this may be either <element /> or <element></element> ).
  3. There is just a single text-type content then delegate to that content's print method
  4. There is only text-type content (more than one though) then delegate to printTextConsecutive(Writer, FormatStack, List, int, int)
  5. There is content other than just text-type content, then delegate to printContent(Writer, FormatStack, NamespaceStack, List)

Parameters:
out - Writer to use.
fstack - the FormatStack
nstack - the NamespaceStack
element - Element to write.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the destination Writer fails

printContent

protected void printContent(java.io.Writer out,
                            FormatStack fstack,
                            NamespaceStack nstack,
                            java.util.List<? extends Content> content)
                     throws java.io.IOException
This will handle printing of a List of Content.

The list of Content is basically processed as one of three types of content

  1. Consecutive text-type (Text, CDATA, and EntityRef) content
  2. Stand-alone text-type content
  3. Non-text-type content.
Although the code looks complex, the theory is conceptually simple:
  1. identify one of the three types (consecutive, stand-alone, non-text)
  2. do indent if any is specified.
  3. send the type to the respective print* handler (e.g. printTextConsecutive(Writer, FormatStack, List, int, int), printCDATA(Writer, FormatStack, CDATA), or printComment(Writer, FormatStack, Comment),
  4. do a newline if one is specified.
  5. loop back to 1. until there's no more content to process.

Parameters:
out - Writer to use.
fstack - the FormatStack
nstack - the NamespaceStack
content - List of Content to write.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the destination Writer fails

printTextConsecutive

protected void printTextConsecutive(java.io.Writer out,
                                    FormatStack fstack,
                                    java.util.List<? extends Content> content,
                                    int offset,
                                    int len)
                             throws java.io.IOException
This will handle printing of a consecutive sequence of text-type Content (CDATA Text, or EntityRef) nodes. It is an error (unspecified Exception or unspecified behaviour) to pass this method any other type of node.

It is a requirement for this method that at least one of the specified text-type instances has non-whitespace, or, put the other way, if all specified text-type values are all white-space only, then you may get odd looking XML (empty lines).

Parameters:
out - Writer to use.
fstack - the FormatStack
content - List of Content to write.
offset - index of first content node (inclusive).
len - number of nodes that are text-type.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the destination Writer fails

helperContentDispatcher

protected void helperContentDispatcher(java.io.Writer out,
                                       FormatStack fstack,
                                       NamespaceStack nstack,
                                       Content content)
                                throws java.io.IOException
This method contains code which is reused in a number of places. It simply determines what content is passed in, and dispatches it to the correct print* method.

Parameters:
out - The destination to write to.
fstack - The current FormatStack
nstack - the NamespaceStack
content - The content to dispatch
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the output fails

helperTextType

protected final void helperTextType(java.io.Writer out,
                                    FormatStack fstack,
                                    java.util.List<? extends Content> content,
                                    int offset,
                                    int len)
                             throws java.io.IOException
This helper determines how much text-type content there is to print. If there is a single node only, then it is dispatched to the respective print* method, otherwise it is dispatched to the printTextConsecutive method.

It is a requirement for this method that at least one of the specified text-type instances has non-whitespace, or, put the other way, if all specified text-type values are all white-space only, then you may get odd looking XML (empty lines).

Odd things can happen too if the len is <= 0;

Parameters:
out - where to write
fstack - the current FormatStack
content - The list of Content to process
offset - The offset of the first text-type content in the sequence
len - the number of text-type content in the sequence
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the output fails.

helperRawTextType

protected final void helperRawTextType(java.io.Writer out,
                                       FormatStack fstack,
                                       Content content)
                                throws java.io.IOException
This method contains code which is reused in a number of places. It simply determines which of the text-type content is passed in, and dispatches it to the correct text method (textEscapeRaw, textCDATARaw, or textEntityRef).

Parameters:
out - The destination to write to.
fstack - The current FormatStack
content - The content to dispatch
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the output fails

                                  int offset,
                                  int len)

true if there's no actual text in the specified content range.
